questions.question: To qualify for head of household filing status, an unmarried taxpayer must:

options.B: Pay more than half the cost of maintaining a home for a qualifying person

questions.explanation: Head of household requires being unmarried, paying more than half the cost of maintaining a home, and having a qualifying person (usually a dependent) live with you for more than half the year. Parents can qualify even if not living with taxpayer.
questions.tip: HOH: Unmarried + >50% home costs + qualifying person living with you (parent exception exists).

questions.question: Under the simplified method for home office deduction, what is the maximum deduction for 2024?
questions.explanation: The simplified method allows $5 per square foot of home office space, up to 300 square feet maximum. Maximum deduction = 300 × $5 = $1,500. No actual expenses need to be tracked.
questions.tip: Home office simplified: $5/sq ft × 300 max sq ft = $1,500 maximum.

questions.question: If a taxpayer uses a dependent care FSA, can they also claim the child and dependent care credit on the same expenses?

options.B: No—expenses paid through FSA reduce eligible credit expenses

questions.explanation: Expenses paid through a dependent care FSA cannot also be used for the credit. The $5,000 FSA benefit reduces the maximum expenses eligible for the credit ($6,000 for 2+ children becomes $1,000 maximum for credit calculation).
questions.tip: No double-dipping: FSA expenses reduce credit-eligible expenses.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a capital asset?

options.B: Investment stocks

questions.explanation: Capital assets include all property except specific exclusions: inventory, depreciable business property, real property used in business, accounts receivable, and certain creative works. Inventory held for sale to customers is NOT a capital asset.
questions.tip: Capital asset = everything EXCEPT inventory, business property, receivables, creative works.

questions.question: Which of the following is an exception to the 10% early withdrawal penalty from a traditional IRA?

options.B: Qualified higher education expenses

questions.explanation: IRA early withdrawal penalty exceptions include: qualified education expenses, first-time home purchase ($10K), medical expenses exceeding 7.5% AGI, health insurance while unemployed, disability, and SEPP payments.
questions.tip: IRA penalty exceptions: Education, first home ($10K), medical, disability, SEPP, others.

questions.question: When must a business issue Form 1099-NEC for payments to an independent contractor?

options.B: For payments of $600 or more during the year

questions.explanation: Form 1099-NEC is required for payments of $600 or more to non-corporate independent contractors for services. Payments to corporations are generally exempt (except attorneys and medical providers).
questions.tip: 1099-NEC: $600+ to non-corp contractors. Due January 31.

questions.question: A partner contributes property with FMV of $100,000 and basis of $40,000 to a partnership. What is the partnership's basis in the property?
questions.explanation: The partnership takes carryover basis in contributed property equal to the contributing partner's basis ($40,000). The partner's outside basis equals the property's basis contributed. No gain is recognized on contribution.
questions.tip: Partnership contribution: Partnership takes carryover basis. Partner gets basis equal to property contributed.

questions.question: Income earned by a revocable living trust during the grantor's lifetime is taxed to:

options.B: The grantor on their individual return

questions.explanation: Revocable trusts are grantor trusts. All income is reported on the grantor's individual return using their SSN. The trust doesn't file a separate return during the grantor's lifetime (or files informational return only).
questions.tip: Revocable trust: Grantor trust. Income taxed to grantor on Form 1040.

questions.question: An S corporation pays $12,000 for health insurance for a shareholder who owns 25% of the stock. How is this treated?

options.B: Included in W-2 wages but deductible by shareholder

questions.explanation: Health insurance for >2% S corp shareholders must be included in W-2 wages (subject to income tax, not FICA). The shareholder can then deduct the premium as self-employed health insurance on page 1 of Form 1040.
questions.tip: >2% S corp shareholder health insurance: W-2 inclusion, then self-employed deduction.

questions.question: For 2024, a married couple filing jointly can have long-term capital gains taxed at 0% if their taxable income doesn't exceed:
questions.explanation: The 0% LTCG rate applies to MFJ taxpayers with taxable income up to $94,050 (2024). From $94,050 to $583,750, the 15% rate applies. Above that, the 20% rate applies (plus potential 3.8% NIIT).
questions.tip: 2024 LTCG brackets (MFJ): 0% to $94K, 15% to $583K, 20% above. Plus potential NIIT.

questions.question: A partnership has $100,000 of recourse debt. Partner A is a 40% general partner and Partner B is a 60% limited partner. How is the debt allocated for basis purposes?
questions.explanation: Recourse liabilities are allocated to partners who bear the economic risk of loss. General partners bear risk; limited partners generally don't. Partner A (general partner) is allocated all $100,000 of recourse debt.
questions.tip: Recourse debt: Allocated to partners bearing economic risk (usually general partners).

questions.question: A taxpayer age 72 with $15,000 in itemizable deductions makes a $10,000 QCD from their IRA. What is the tax benefit compared to taking a distribution and donating cash?

options.B: QCD excludes income; cash donation provides no benefit if using standard deduction

questions.explanation: QCDs exclude the distribution from income entirely. If the taxpayer takes the standard deduction ($29,200 MFJ), a cash donation provides no tax benefit. QCDs provide benefit regardless of itemizing status.
questions.tip: QCD advantage: Excludes income entirely. Benefits standard deduction users most.

questions.question: A C corporation with E&P of $30,000 distributes $50,000 to its sole shareholder (basis $15,000). How is the distribution taxed?

options.B: $30,000 dividend, $15,000 return of capital, $5,000 capital gain

questions.explanation: Distributions come from: (1) E&P = dividend, (2) stock basis = tax-free return of capital, (3) excess = capital gain. Here: $30,000 dividend + $15,000 return of basis + $5,000 capital gain.
questions.tip: C corp distribution ordering: E&P (dividend) → basis (tax-free) → excess (capital gain).

questions.question: An installment sale involves Section 1245 property with $50,000 of depreciation recapture. How is the recapture reported?

options.B: Entirely in year of sale

questions.explanation: Depreciation recapture (Section 1245 ordinary income) cannot be deferred under installment sale rules. It must be recognized entirely in the year of sale, regardless of when payments are received.
questions.tip: Installment sale: Recapture recognized in year of sale. Only Section 1231 gain deferred.

questions.question: A complex trust wants to treat a January distribution as made in the prior year. This election under Section 663(b) must be made within:

options.B: 65 days of year-end
options.D: By the extended return due date

questions.explanation: The 65-day rule allows trustees to elect to treat distributions made within 65 days after year-end as made on the last day of the prior year. This helps distribute income to beneficiaries and avoid compressed trust rates.
questions.tip: 65-day rule: Distributions by March 6 can be treated as prior year. Avoids trust taxation.

questions.question: Under a state's throwback rule, sales of tangible personal property shipped to a state where the seller is not taxable are:

options.B: Thrown back to the state of origin

questions.explanation: Throwback rules assign 'nowhere' sales (sales to states where seller has no nexus) back to the state of shipment origin. This prevents sales from escaping state taxation entirely.
questions.tip: Throwback: Nowhere sales assigned to origin state. Some states also have 'throwout' rules.

questions.question: A 55-year-old participant in a 401(k) plan can make additional catch-up contributions of how much in 2024?
questions.explanation: 401(k) catch-up contributions for those 50+ are $7,500 for 2024. Combined with the $23,000 regular limit, maximum employee deferral is $30,500. IRA catch-up is only $1,000.
questions.tip: 2024 catch-up: 401(k) = $7,500; IRA = $1,000. Both for age 50+.

questions.question: When are restricted stock units (RSUs) taxed?

options.B: Vesting date when shares are delivered

questions.explanation: RSUs are taxed as ordinary income when the shares vest and are delivered to the employee. Unlike restricted stock, there is no Section 83(b) election available for RSUs because no property is transferred at grant.
questions.tip: RSU taxation: Vesting/delivery date = ordinary income. No 83(b) election available.

questions.question: The energy efficient home improvement credit under Section 25C has an annual limit of:
questions.explanation: The Section 25C credit provides up to $1,200 annually for most improvements (insulation, windows, doors) plus an additional $2,000 for heat pumps/water heaters. Total maximum = $3,200 annually.
questions.tip: Section 25C: $1,200 general + $2,000 heat pump = $3,200 max per year. Annual reset.

questions.question: A passive activity with $100,000 suspended losses is sold for $200,000 gain using an installment sale (40% received in year 1). How much suspended loss is released in year 1?
questions.explanation: Suspended passive losses are released proportionately with gain recognition in installment sales. Year 1: 40% of gain recognized = 40% × $100,000 suspended loss = $40,000 released.
questions.tip: Installment sale of PAL activity: Losses released pro rata with gain recognition.

questions.question: A U.S. person who is a 15% partner in a foreign partnership must file Form 8865 if they:

options.A: Have any interest in a foreign partnership
options.B: Control the partnership or made certain transfers
options.D: Form 8865 is never required for 15% partners

questions.explanation: Form 8865 is required for U.S. persons who control foreign partnerships, have certain acquisition/disposition thresholds, or make transfers exceeding $100,000. A 15% partner without control may not have a filing requirement.
questions.tip: Form 8865: Controlling U.S. persons, transfers >$100K, acquisitions/dispositions. Not all partners file.

questions.question: The alternate valuation date for estate tax purposes is:

options.B: Six months after death

questions.explanation: Estates can elect to value assets 6 months after death (or date of earlier disposition) instead of date of death. The election is only available if it reduces both estate value and estate tax liability.
questions.tip: Alternate valuation: 6 months post-death. Must reduce both estate value AND tax.

questions.question: Which business can generally use the cash method of accounting?

options.A: Any business with gross receipts under $29 million
options.B: Only sole proprietorships
options.C: C corporations with over $50 million revenue

questions.explanation: Businesses with average annual gross receipts of $29 million or less (2024, indexed) for the prior 3 years can use the cash method. This includes farming, services, and small manufacturing. Tax shelters and certain inventory businesses have restrictions.
questions.tip: Cash method: Available to businesses ≤$29M average gross receipts (3-year test).

questions.question: Under the rental real estate safe harbor for Section 199A, how many hours of rental services must be performed annually?

options.B: 250 hours

questions.explanation: The safe harbor requires at least 250 hours of rental services per year (or in any 3 of 5 consecutive years). Separate books must be maintained, and the rental cannot be rented to a commonly controlled business.
questions.tip: 199A rental safe harbor: 250 hours + separate books + not rented to controlled business.

questions.question: The statute of limitations for assessment extends from 3 to 6 years if the taxpayer:

options.B: Omits more than 25% of gross income

questions.explanation: The 6-year statute applies when gross income is understated by more than 25%. For 6-year purposes, gross income includes cost basis overstatements that reduce reported gain. Fraud has no statute of limitations.
questions.tip: 6-year statute: >25% gross income omission. No limit for fraud.

questions.question: In a Section 1031 exchange, replacement property must be identified within:

options.B: 45 days

questions.explanation: Replacement property must be identified within 45 days of the sale. The property must be acquired within 180 days (or by tax return due date if earlier). The 3-property rule or 200% rule limits identification options.
questions.tip: 1031 timing: 45 days to identify, 180 days to close. 3-property or 200% rule.

questions.question: Under current law, when does a partnership terminate for tax purposes?

options.A: When 50%+ of interests are sold within 12 months
options.B: Only when business operations cease or there is only one partner
options.D: When original partners no longer hold majority

questions.explanation: TCJA eliminated the technical termination rule (50% sale in 12 months). Partnerships now only terminate when: (1) no business continues, or (2) only one partner remains. This simplifies continuation of tax attributes.
questions.tip: Post-TCJA: No more technical terminations. Only business cessation or single partner ends partnership.

questions.question: Section 2032A allows farmland to be valued at its actual use value rather than highest and best use. What is the maximum reduction from FMV for 2024?
questions.explanation: Section 2032A allows special use valuation with maximum reduction of $1,390,000 (2024, indexed) from fair market value. Requirements include material participation, 50% qualified real property, 25% business test, and qualified heir rules.
questions.tip: Section 2032A: Up to $1.39M reduction. Strict qualification and recapture rules.

questions.question: An S corporation inadvertently becomes ineligible (e.g., issues second class of stock). What relief is available?

options.B: IRS can waive termination if inadvertent and corrected
options.C: Election can be renewed after 1 year
options.D: Shareholders must pay penalty to maintain election

questions.explanation: The IRS can provide relief for inadvertent terminations under Section 1362(f) if: (1) the termination was inadvertent, (2) steps are taken to correct the issue, and (3) shareholders agree to adjustments. Private letter ruling typically required.
questions.tip: Inadvertent S termination: IRS relief available. Correct promptly and request PLR.

questions.question: Under Section 280G, an excess parachute payment triggers:

options.B: 20% excise tax on executive only
options.C: Nondeductibility by corporation and 20% excise tax on executive

questions.explanation: Excess parachute payments (payments exceeding 3× base amount) result in: (1) no corporate deduction for excess amounts, and (2) 20% excise tax paid by the executive. Both penalties apply, creating significant tax cost.
questions.tip: Golden parachute: >3× base = no deduction + 20% excise. Double penalty.

questions.question: The base erosion and anti-abuse tax (BEAT) applies to corporations with average annual gross receipts exceeding:

options.B: $100 million

questions.explanation: BEAT applies to corporations with average annual gross receipts of $500 million+ and base erosion percentage of 3%+ (2% for banks). It's a minimum tax on modified taxable income at 10% (12.5% for 2026+).
questions.tip: BEAT: $500M+ gross receipts, 3%+ base erosion. Minimum tax on deductible related-party payments.

questions.question: How is S corporation income taxed in an electing small business trust (ESBT)?

options.B: At highest individual marginal rate on a separate portion

questions.explanation: ESBT S corp income is taxed at the highest individual rate (37%) on a separate 'S portion' of the trust. This differs from regular trust taxation and cannot be distributed to beneficiaries to use their lower rates.
questions.tip: ESBT S corp income: Taxed at highest individual rate (37%). Separate computation.

questions.question: For wash sale purposes, which of the following is NOT considered substantially identical to stock sold at a loss?

options.B: An option to acquire the same stock
options.C: Stock in a different company in the same industry
options.D: A contract to acquire the same stock

questions.explanation: Substantially identical means the same security or rights to acquire it. Stock in a different company, even in the same industry or tracking the same index, is generally NOT substantially identical. ETFs tracking same index may raise questions.
questions.tip: Substantially identical: Same stock or rights to acquire it. Different company = not identical.

questions.question: For Section 382 purposes, an ownership change occurs when 5% shareholders increase their ownership by more than:

options.B: 50 percentage points over 3 years

questions.explanation: An ownership change occurs when the percentage of stock owned by 5% shareholders increases by more than 50 percentage points over a 3-year testing period. This triggers the Section 382 NOL limitation.
questions.tip: Section 382: >50% ownership shift by 5% shareholders in 3 years = ownership change.

questions.question: Under SECURE 2.0, employer matching contributions to a 401(k) can now be designated as:

options.B: Roth contributions (employee's choice)

questions.explanation: SECURE 2.0 allows employers to offer employees the option to receive matching or nonelective contributions as Roth contributions (taxable when contributed). Previously, employer contributions were always pre-tax.
questions.tip: SECURE 2.0: Roth employer match option. Employee can elect taxable match for tax-free growth.
